properties.name: Login Protection
properties.tagline: Add protections to your WordPress login forms and protect user accounts with 2-Factor Authentication.

sections.title: Brute Force Login Guard
summary: Purpose - Blocks brute force hacking attacks against your login and registration pages.
Recommendation - Use of this feature is highly recommend.

sections.title: Multi-Factor Authentication
summary: Purpose - Verifies the identity of users who log in to your site - i.e. they are who they say they are.
Recommendation - Use of this feature is highly recommend. However, if your host blocks email sending you may lock yourself out.
Note: You may combine multiple authentication factors for increased security.

sections.title: Email Two-Factor Authentication
summary: Purpose - Verifies the identity of users who log in to your site using email-based one-time-passwords.
Recommendation - Use of this feature is highly recommend. However, if your host blocks email sending you may lock yourself out.
Note: You may combine multiple authentication factors for increased security.

sections.title: One-Time Passwords
summary: Purpose - Verifies the identity of users who log in to your site using Google Authenticator one-time-passwords.
Recommendation - Use of this feature is highly recommend. However, if your host blocks email sending you may lock yourself out.
Note: You may combine multiple authentication factors for increased security.

sections.title: Hardware 2-Factor Authentication
summary: Purpose - Verifies the identity of users who log in to your site using Yubikey one-time-passwords.
Note: You may combine multiple authentication factors for increased security.

sections.title: Hide WP Login Page
summary: Purpose - To hide your wp-login.php page from brute force attacks and hacking attempts - if your login page cannot be found, no-one can login.
Recommendation - This is not required for complete security and if your site has irregular or inconsistent configuration it may not work for you.

sections.title: Disable Login Guard Module
summary: Purpose - Login Guard blocks all automated and brute force attempts to log in to your site.
Recommendation - Keep the Login Guard module turned on.

sections.title: Deprecated
summary: These options will be removed in the future. Please use the ADE option under Bot SPAM section.

options.name: Enable Login Guard
options.summary: Enable (or Disable) The Login Guard Module
options.description: Un-Checking this option will completely disable the Login Guard module

options.name: Hide WP Login & Admin
options.summary: Hide The WordPress Login And Admin Areas
options.description: Creating a path here will disable your 'wp-login.php'. Only letters and numbers are permitted: abc123

options.name: WP Login & Admin Redirect
options.summary: Automatic Redirect URL For Hidden Pages
options.description: Automatically redirect requests to this location for the hidden pages.

options.name: MFA Verification Page

options.name: 2FA Remember Me
options.summary: A User Can Bypass Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) For The Set Number Of Days
options.description: Enter the number of days a user can bypass future MFA after a successful MFA-login. 0 to disable.

options.name: Allow Backup Codes
options.summary: Allow Users To Generate A Backup Code
options.description: Allow users to generate a backup code that can be used to login if MFA factors are unavailable.

options.name: Enable Google Authenticator
options.summary: Allow Users To Use Google Authenticator
options.description: When enabled, users will have the option to add Google Authenticator to their WordPress user profile.

options.name: Allow Yubikey OTP

options.name: Yubikey App ID

options.description: Combined with your Yubikey API Key this will form the basis of your Yubikey Authentication.

options.name: Yubikey API Key
options.summary: Your Unique Yubikey App API Key
options.description: Combined with your Yubikey App ID this will form the basis of your Yubikey Authentication.

options.name: Enable SMS Auth
options.summary: Enable SMS Authentication
options.description: When enabled, users will have the option to add SMS Auth to their WordPress user profile.

options.name: Enable Email Authentication
options.summary: Two-Factor Login Authentication By Email
options.description: All users will be required to verify their login by email-based two-factor authentication.

options.name: Email Auto-Login
options.summary: Enable Email Auto-Login Links
options.description: 2FA Email will contain an auto-login link so the user doesn't need to enter 2FA code manually.

options.name: Enforce - Email Authentication
options.summary: All User Roles Subject To Email Authentication
options.description: Enforces email-based authentication on all users with the selected roles. Note: This setting only applies to email authentication.

options.name: Allow Any User
options.summary: Allow Any User To Turn-On Two-Factor Authentication By Email
options.description: Allow Any User To Turn-On Two-Factor Authentication By Email.

options.name: AntiBot
options.summary: Use AntiBot Detection Engine
options.description: Use Shield's AntiBot Detection Engine To Block Bots and Brute Force Attacks

options.name: Protection Locations
options.summary: How Google reCAPTCHA Will Be Displayed
options.description: Choose for which forms bot protection measures will be deployed.

options.name: Login Cooldown Interval
options.summary: Limit login attempts to every X seconds
options.description: WordPress will process only ONE login attempt for every number of seconds specified. Zero (0) turns this off.

options.name: Bot Protection
options.summary: Protect WP Login From Automated Login Attempts By Bots
options.description: Adds a dynamically (Javascript) generated checkbox to the login form that prevents bots using automated login techniques. Recommended: ON.

options.name: AntiBot Forms
options.summary: Enter The IDs Of The 3rd Party Login Forms For Use With AntiBot JS
options.description: For Use With AnitBot JS (above).

options.name: Enable Passkeys
